titles.title: Leaping Men, from Animal Locomotion series

makers.displaydate: 1830–1904; born Kingston upon Thames, United Kingdom; died Kingston upon Thames, United Kingdom; active San Francisco, CA
makers.displaymaker: Eadweard Muybridge, 1830–1904; born Kingston upon Thames, United Kingdom; died Kingston upon Thames, United Kingdom; active San Francisco, CA

texts.textentryhtml: [Howard Greenberg Gallery, New York, NY]; acquired by J. Michael Parish; given to the Princeton University Art Museum, 2016.

From the time of photography’s invention, photographers were excited about the new medium’s possibilities and understood its scientific potential. Muybridge was the first to successfully document and analyze the motion of animals and humans by taking multiple photographs in rapid succession and displaying them side by side. These series answered many questions about motion that had eluded the human eye, the most famous of which was whether all of a running horse’s legs leave the ground simultaneously. Perhaps more significantly, these images, projected one after the other, became one of the first iterations of motion pictures. In Leaping Men, Muybridge created a study of motion through a physical interaction between two men, capturing the musculature of the human form and locomotion over time.
texts.remarks: Franz History of Photography Rotation July 2017
